CeO2 has been widely explored for CO2 conversion due to its suitable properties to activate CO2 molecules.223–228 Thus, numerous works have reported the high potential of CeO2 for the direct synthesis of dialkyl and cyclic carbonates.219,228,229 However, the main limitations of CeO2 is its easy deactivation by water, therefore the control of hydrophobic and hydrophilic properties of the catalytic surface can play a key role. Accordingly, the hydrophobicity of Ce/SBA-15 catalysts was varied by silylation of OH group with hexamethyldisilazane.230 The catalytic behavior of the silylated samples revealed that the catalytic activity was related to the amount of moderate acid sites enabling the activation of methanol and to the hydrophobicity that allowed reducing the deactivation by water adsorption. Then, hydrophobic catalysts exhibited higher activity than hydrophilic samples. The highest 0.2% DMC yield close to equilibrium value was obtained in the presence of Ce/SBA-15–6 hydrophobic catalyst at 130 °C, 12 h and 12 MPa.


1.2.3 Zeolite-based catalysts for the synthesis of dialkyl carbonates. In order to shift the equilibrium of the process, the effectiveness of different strategic organic and inorganic dehydrating agents have been reported such as ketals,231 orthoesters,232 and epoxides,233 molecular sieves.234 Among them ketals present different advantages such as price, availability, harmless and chemical neutrality. Alcohol and ketone react to produce a ketal and water which reversibly give back alcohol and ketone. During the dialkyl carbonate formation, advantage of the production of water could be taken to hydrolyze the acetal and produce alcohols and ketones. Accordingly, the efficient combination of CeO2 and H-FAU as a solid and recyclable catalyst to perform direct diethyl carbonate (DEC) synthesis from CO2 and ethanol in the presence of DEP (2,2-dimethoxy propane) as a dehydrating agent was described. Different zeolites with similar and optimized Si/Al close to 25 were checked but higher DEC yield and selectivity were achieved in the presence of the FAU zeolite. Therefore, a 62% high DEC yield based on DEP was obtained at 120 °C and 6.5 MPa CO2 after 24 h of reaction. Moreover, the stability of the catalytic system was shown over 4 cycles.235 Previously, the catalytic data of the DEC synthesis in the presence of ZrO2 as catalyst and 3A molecular sieve as co-catalyst showed the improved DEC yield, about 2.5-fold, induced by the presence of molecular sieve. In optimized reaction conditions, 150 °C and 7 MPa and ZrO2/3A ratio of 5:2, 0.384 mmol DEC yield was obtained after 2 h with 85% selectivity.
1.2.4 Conclusions. The direct synthesis of dialkyl carbonates is a difficult task due to the thermodynamics and the reversibility of the process. Moreover, the production of water constitutes another limitation and induces a rapid deactivation of the catalysts and hydrolysis of the carbonates. Very few attempts to design and develop heterogeneous catalytic systems have been investigated and this remains a topic to be explored. Zeolites and ordered mesopore-based catalysts, due to their versatility in accommodating different types of active sites and the possibility to control their hydrophobic properties, should be good candidates to develop active and efficient catalysts to activate both CO2 and ROH molecules and remove water through chemical transformation or rapid desorption from the catalytic surface. Moreover, the development of knowledge and insights into the elucidation of catalytic species, intermediates and substrates through theoretical calculations, characterization and modeling studies should be of great value to rationalize experimental data and design new efficient and recyclable catalysts.

2 Synthesis of carbamates

Organic carbamates are an important class of chemicals that find applications in a variety of polymers (polyurethanes), agrochemicals,236,237 drugs and medicines,238 and intermediates of fine and commodity chemicals.239–241 The carbamate group features a particular stability due to the delocalization of the non-bonding electrons on the N-atom into the carboxyl moiety. This specific stability allows improving the pharmacokinetic properties of drugs and that is the reason for the presence of this functional group in many pharmaceuticals (Fig. 12).242–244 As such, more than 10000 tons of carbamates per year are used in the agriculture.245 The production of carbamates currently proceeds through the alcoholysis of isocyanates or aminolysis of chloroformates,246–248 because the preparation of isocyanates and chloroformates are originated from highly toxic and corrosive phosgene.249,250 Thus the use of anthropogenic CO2 as the C1 source for the preparation of carbamates is very topical and numerous works have been reported.251,252 Different approaches have been attempted for the production of carbamates from CO2 and amines, and different substrates such as alcohols, metal alkoxide, epoxide and alkyl halides. Nevertheless, several limitations as high CO2 pressure, long reaction times, use of homogeneous catalysts, low yields and limited scope need to be improved for a successful application. Thus, the rational design and development of efficient and recyclable heterogeneous catalysts for the synthesis of carbamates from CO2 is still topical.
Fig. 12 Scheme of carbamate applications.
2.1 Synthesis of acyclic carbamates.
2.1.1 Introduction. As aforementioned, in the literature different pathways using CO2 as the carboxyl moiety for the preparation of acyclic carbamates have been widely studied (Scheme 35). Nevertheless, the synthesis of acyclic carbamates presents thermodynamic limitations and harsh reaction conditions are generally required. Numerous catalytic systems such as metal-based catalysts (Al, Sn, Ru, Zn, and Fe),253–255 base (DBU)241,256,257 and alkali metal salts have been described for the preparation of carbamates (Scheme 35).258,259 However, few attempts involved the use of ordered microporous and mesoporous based catalysts as catalysts or as support, and only the synthesis of acyclic carbamates following the three components coupling of amine, RX and CO2 pathway has been described in the presence of these types of materials.
Scheme 35 Synthesis pathways of acyclic carbamates.

2.1.2 Three component coupling of amine, RX and CO2 for the synthesis of carbamates. Among the different possible pathways, oxidative carbonylation of amine represents a sustainable and eco-friendly pathway for producing organic carbamates (R1NHCO2R2) from CO2 (Scheme 36). The reaction of CO2 and amine provides a carbamate anion which, after reaction with an alkyl halide, yields a carbamate. In the absence of a catalyst, the amine alkylation also occurs and constitutes the main side product. To minimize undesired reaction, different catalysts have been used such as base catalysts (DBU, alkali metal salts),260–264 alkyl-onium salts265,266 and metal based catalysts (Pd, Zn).263,267 In the literature, only few examples describing the use of OMS based catalysts was reported.
Scheme 36 Oxidative carbonylation of amine in the presence of alkyl halides.

(a) Zeolite-based catalysts for the three component coupling of amine, RX and CO2. Zeolite-beta synthesized with tetraethylammonium bromide (TEABr) as the structure directing agent (SDA) was used as a catalyst for the synthesis of aryl carbamates by oxidative carbonylation of amines with CO2.268 Aliphatic and aromatic carbamates were obtained with high selectivity 84–95% without solvent requirement, at 80 °C and 0.34 MPa CO2 pressure (Table 2, entries 1–6). The order of reactivity with amines was the following: octylamine > cyclohexylamine > hexylamine > benzylamine > aniline > 2,4,6-trimethyl aniline, the reactivity of aliphatic amines being higher than that of aromatic amines. Previously, the same group reported the catalytic performance of different titanosilicate molecular sieves (TS-1, Ti-MCM-41, Ti-SBA-15) and metal phthalocyanine complexes encapsulated in zeolite-Y for the synthesis of carbamates.268,269 Alkyl and aryl carbamates were synthesized with high yields >80% in the presence of TS-1, and in the case of bulky substrates like 2,4,6-trimethylaniline and cyclododecylamine, the mesoporous Ti-SBA-15 was more active than TS-1, at 80 °C and 0.34 MPa CO2 pressure (Table 2, entries 7–13). Similarly, metal phthalocyanines encapsulated in Y zeolite exhibited efficient catalytic activity under the same reaction conditions, and butyl-N-phenyl carbamate was prepared with 75% yield. Likewise, the same group described the catalytic performance of an organo-functionalized mesoporous titanosilicate (SBA-15) with the adenine group for the formation of carbonates and carbamates using CO2 as the raw material.207 The presence of both, titanium ions (weak Lewis acid sites) and the amine moieties (the basic sites), was required to maximize the carbamate yield. Aliphatic and aromatic carbamates were prepared with high selectivity (84–85%), even without the solvent, the aliphatic amines being more reactive (Table 2, entries 14–19). However, the main drawback of these methodologies is the need for a strong donor solvent like DMF.
Table 2 Summary of the different catalytic systems and reaction conditions for oxidative carboxylation of amines
Entry Catalysts Conditions Substrates Yield/selectivity (%) Catalyst/substrate Year Ref.
1 Beta zeolite/TEABr 80 °C, 0.34 MPa, 4 h 91.7/91.7 150 mg/10 mmol amine/10 mmol n-butylBr 2005 268
2 79.9/84.2
3 85.5/88.6
4 45.9/86.9
5 68.6/90
6 20/95.2
7 TS-1 80 °C, 0.34 MPa, 3 h 86.4/94.5 DMF: 10 g 2004 269
8 89.5/96.5 2 mmol amine/2 mmol n-butylBr
9 58.5/92.5 100 mg TS-1
10 89.3/96
11 63.4/95.2
12 54.8/97.8
13 CuPc_Y 74.9/80 2 mmol amine/6 mmol n-butylBr
83 mg CuPc_Y
14 80 °C, 0.34 MPa, 4 h 84.9/88 10 mmol amine/12 mmol n-butylBr 2005 207
15 92.4/93.5 100 mg catalyst
16 76/83.5
17 89/89
18 82.2/92.8
19 65.5/87.8
20 80 °C, 0.34 MPa, 3 h 85.4/94.5 10 mmol amine/10 mmol n-butylBr 2006 177
21 90.1/90.1
22 75.8/80.6 150 mg catalyst
23 42.7/83.7
24 69.2/91
25 28.4/94.8


(b) Ordered mesoporous based catalysts for the three component coupling of amine, RX and CO2. The synthesis and catalytic activity of an as-synthesized form of MCM-41 with cetyltrimethylammonium bromide as SDA for the production of carbamates was also described.177 The coupling reaction of CO2, n-butyl-bromide and N-alkyl and N-aryl amines was performed with high selectivity and without solvent at 80 °C and 0.34 MPa CO2 pressure, nevertheless, recyclability of the MCM-41 catalyst was not explored (Table 2, entries 20–25). The catalytic activity of the same materials was also reported for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates.
(c) Conclusions. The syntheses of acyclic carbamates have been scarcely investigated in the presence of zeolites and OMS based catalysts although good yield and selectivity were reached. The recyclability of the catalysts should be further explored and reaction conditions improved for achieving potential application. This process generally requires highly active and selective homogeneous organometallic complexes and strong bases, and it is of interest to find heterogeneous alternatives. Today, it is still difficult to transfer the remarkable catalytic activity of homogeneous organometallic complexes to solid catalysts. Nevertheless, recent developments in the rational design of solid catalysts with well defined single or multiple active sites, can help in the synthesis of tailor made hybrid organic–inorganic structured materials containing one or the two required catalytic functions. This last could be a good direction in the achievement of more successful solid catalysts for the synthesis of acyclic carbamates.
2.2 Synthesis of 2-oxazolidinones.
2.2.1 Introduction. Oxazolidinones are heterocyclic compounds containing N and O in a 5-member ring with a wide scope of applications in chemical synthesis for the production of chiral auxiliaries,270 agrochemicals271 and pharmaceuticals, such as antidepressants272 and antitumor drugs.273 Moreover, 2-oxazolidinones represent a novel class of synthetic antimicrobial agents exhibiting a potent activity against Gram-positive organisms.274–277 Besides, 2-oxazolidinones have found application as a solvent for lithium-ion batteries278 and ink-jet printing.279

Classically, 2-oxazolidinones are prepared from aminoalcohols and carbonyl group sources such as phosgene, carbonate and isocyanate.280,281 The other important route of synthesis involves the reaction of epoxides with isocyanates.282,283 As was mentioned above, alternatives to the use of reactant issue from phosgene and phosgene are of great interest to avoid its toxicity, the associated production of corrosive salts and hazardous storage and handling. Therefore, the use of CO2 is an environmentally friendly promising and challengeable alternative to the use of toxic, harmful and costly substrates.284,285 In the last two decades, a series of CO2 fixation pathways for the preparation of functionalized 2-oxazolidinones, such as cycloaddition of CO2 with aziridines,284 CO2 fixation through cyclisation with unsaturated compounds such as propargylamines,284,286 allylic and α-allenylic amines,287 and coupling of propargylic alcohols, amines and CO2,285 dehydrative condensation of β-amino alcohols284,288,289 and condensation with epoxyamine have been explored (Scheme 37).


Scheme 37 CO2 fixation pathways to the production of substituted 2-oxazolidinones.

Works have been published on different synthetic routes to fix anthropogenic CO2 into 2-oxazolidinones in the presence of organometallic complexes, metal salts, organocatalysts (ionic liquid, quaternary ammonium, phosphine and bases). Attempts for heterogenisation290–294 of organocatalysts and organometallic complexes were explored as well as the possibilities of MOFs as catalysts.295,296 Nevertheless, the use of ordered micro and mesoporous materials has been almost unexplored.


2.2.2 Cycloaddition of CO2 with aziridine. The cycloaddition of CO2 with aziridine constitutes an important route to mitigate the excess emissions while preparing high value-added chemicals (Scheme 37) through the chemical fixation of CO2 with 100% atom efficiency. Numerous studies have focused on the synthesis and reactivity of aziridines since they are an important tool in organic chemistry owing to the high reactivity of the ring-strain that at the same time makes them unstable.297 The cycloaddition proceeds in three steps: the first and limiting step is the ring opening of N-heterocycle through nucleophilic attack, followed by the attack of the formed zwitterion to CO2 molecule to provide a carbamate. The last step is the intramolecular cyclization via a nucleophilic attack (Scheme 38).
Scheme 38 Common cycloaddition mechanism between aziridine and CO2 under aziridine ring activation and nucleophilic attack.

Though a large variety of homogeneous catalysts exhibited high catalytic performance for cycloaddition, such as ionic liquids,298,299 alkali metal salts,300–303 quaternary ammonium,304 metal salts305 and metal complexes,306–308 these catalytic systems usually operate under harsh reaction conditions (high temperature and pressure). In addition to the main disadvantages of homogeneous catalysts such as non-recyclability, production of wastes, the described synthesis routes commonly involve expensive catalysts and limited substrate scope.309 Very few works using OMS-based materials were reported and none zeolites-based. Cycloaddition of CO2 with aziridine in the presence of heterogeneous catalysts is an underdeveloped synthesis route, worth to be thoroughly explored.

Due to their properties such as large pore size and high surface area, ordered mesoporous materials offer numerous possibilities to support and immobilize homogeneous catalysts. Recently, amine functionalized MCM-41 catalyst were prepared and used for the synthesis of oxazolidinones, expecting that hydrogen bonding of primary amine groups with nitrogen atom of aziridines could accelerate the ring opening of aziridines.310 The hybrid catalyst exhibited high catalytic activity for the synthesis of numerous 5-aryl-2-oxazolidinones with high yield up to 98%, at 40–80 °C and high 5 MPa CO2 pressure. Moreover, the catalyst showed high stability and recyclability. The yield of 3-butyl-5-phenyloxazolidin-2-one was maintained for five consecutive recycles. A mechanism via zwitterions was described. The nucleophilic attack of the carbamate ion lead to the main product of the reaction derived from ring-opening of the aziridine at the hindered carbon (5-substituted oxazolidinone) (Table 3, entries 1–7).

Table 3 Summary of the different catalytic systems and reaction conditions for CO2 and aziridines cycloaddition
Entry Catalysts Conditions Substrates Yield/selectivity (%) Catalyst/substrate Year Ref.
5-subs./4-subs.
1 120 °C, 1.6 MPa, 6 h 100/92, 95:5 25 wt%/1 mmol 2014 310
2 100/96, 96:4
3 199/97, 99:1
4 100/92, 99:1
5 98/90, 98:2
6 80/65, 91:9
7 100/98, 99:1
8 100 °C, 2 MPa, 24 h 99/95, 64:36 20 mg/2 mmol 2011 311
9 99/92, 92:8 1.5 mL CH2Cl2
10 99/94, 100:0
11 83/80, 100:0

Previously, an N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) functionalized MCM-41 was synthesized and used as catalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides and aziridines (Scheme 39). The authors showed that the NHC–CO2 adduct was the catalytic active species. Different oxazolidinones were obtained with excellent yield and regioselectivity, under mild reactions conditions, 100 °C and 2 MPa CO2 pressure (Table 3, entries 8–11).311


Scheme 39 Catalyzed cycloaddition of aziridines with CO2.
2.3 Conclusion. Several investigations have focused on substituting toxic carbonylating agents by inexpensive, nontoxic and accessible CO2. Nevertheless, due to the CO2 inertness, the CO2 fixation to produce 2-oxazolidines is a difficult task and several limitations such as moderate yields and selectivity, the use of large amounts of homogeneous catalysts and harsh reaction conditions constitute impediments for the high-scale production. Therefore, the design and development of efficient, selective, recyclable and economic catalysts is still challenging. Today, we have knowledge and tools for the rational design of micro and mesoporous materials that can act as molecular sieves for reactant selection, while containing well-isolated single or multiple active sites accommodated on the zeolite walls, and so accessible to reactants through their diffusion. From there, materials could be developed with regular pores and cavities, even by “ab initio” synthesis312 that can control the reactant adsorption and transition-state stabilization and supplying the desired process selectivity.313 Besides, kinetic, theoretical and modelling studies, are still required to a rational design of the catalysts. Then, owing to their robustness, versatility in their possibilities of functionalization, and zeolite and OMS-based catalytic systems containing multi-active centers for activation of CO2 molecules and others components of the different CO2 fixation pathways may offer opportunities worth being explored for the production of carbamates.

3 Other formation of C–N bond

The use of CO2 as C1 building block is of great interest, and as aforementioned the main disadvantage is thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertness of CO2. The use of high-energy substrate such as epoxide and aziridine constitutes an effective strategy for the fixation of CO2, and among the active substrates, amines are good candidates for the formation of new C–N bond.252,314,315 Important examples are the synthesis of urea, carbamates or oxazolidinones and polyurethanes.

Quinazoline-2,4(1H,3H)-dione constitutes an important class of nitrogen-containing heterocycles with biological activities that find a large number of applications as pharmaceuticals.316–319 The synthesis of quinazoline-2,4(1H,3H)-dione derivatives starting from non-toxic, low cost and readily available substrates such as CO2 and 2-aminobenzonitrile is of great interest and constitutes an environmentally friendly process with 100% atom efficiency and an alternative route to the use of toxic phosgene, carbamates,320 anthranilic acids with urea,321,322 potassium cyanate and chlorosulfonyl isocyanate.319 A new, straightforward and overall green synthetic route of quinazoline-2,4(1H,3H)-dione in the presence of DBU has been reported. In the presence of a base catalyst, the formation of quinazoline-2,4(1H,3H)-dione involves the nucleophilic attack of the amino group on CO2. After cyclization, aperture and new cyclization, quinazoline-2,4(1H,3H)-dione is produced (Scheme 40).


Scheme 40 Synthesis of quinazoline-2,4(1H,3H)-dione by carbonylation of 2-aminobenzonitrile and CO2.

The use of CO2 and 2-aminobenzonitrile in the preparation of quinazoline-2,4(1H,3H)-dione is a recent synthesis pathway and has to be further explored. In fact, we have found two references using ordered micro or mesoporous materials. Recently, mesoporous basic zeolite for various transformations involving large organic molecules have been synthesized154 and functionalized with primary, secondary, and tertiary amines via a post-synthetic method via covalent bonding. Accordingly, nanocrystalline zeolite (Nano-ZSM-5) functionalized with basic ionic liquids was used for the quinazoline-2,4(1H,3H)-dione synthesis. Under optimized reaction conditions, 150 °C, 12 h, in protic solvent (DMF), selected CO2 pressure (3.5 MPa), 93.6% yield was achieved.166 The same group previously reported the use of covalent amine (3-(2-(2-aminoethylamino) ethylamino) propyltrimethoxysilane, AEPTMS) functionalized MCM-41, as an efficient and recyclable catalyst for the synthesis of a variety of quinazoline-2,4(1H,3H)-dione compounds from substituted 2-aminobenzonitriles and CO2 in water.323 Solvent played a fundamental role and highly polar solvents were adequate for achieving high yield, the best yields being achieved in DMF and water. Under optimized reaction conditions, at 130 °C, 18 h and 3.5 MPa CO2 pressure, 91% quinazoline-2,4(1H,3H)-dione yield was achieved. The successful scope of the catalyst, as well as the possibility of reusing the catalyst for five consecutive recycles was shown for various substrates.

4 Synthesis of carboxylic acid

4.1 Carboxylation reaction via CO2 insertion into the C–M bond for the synthesis of carboxylic acid. Carboxylic acids constitutes an important class of commodity chemicals with numerous applications as solvents, intermediates for pharmaceuticals, flavors and fragrances and monomers for polymer productions. Carboxylic acid is usually prepared by oxidation of hydrocarbons with the exception of acetic acid that are issued from carbonylation of methanol.

The production of carboxylic acid from CO2 insertion into the C–H bond is a green and atom economic reaction. Nevertheless, this reaction is thermodynamically unfavourable, being both endothermic and entropically disfavoured. Thus, this transformation is very challenging and the design and preparation of new catalysts to overcome this kinetic barrier is of great interest. Then, the preparation of carboxylic acids via carboxylation of alkanes by insertion of CO2 into a C-metal bond is still at an early stage and offers numerous research opportunities.

4.2 Synthesis of acetic acid.
4.2.1 Introduction. Acetic acid is an important raw material in the chemical industry for the production of vinyl acetate and acetic anhydride. Acetic acid is produced by fermentation and chemical routes. Every year, 7 Mt of acetic acid are produced and 190 kt are issued from fermentation. Carbonylation of methanol, oxidation of aldehyde and oxidation of ethylene are the main chemical pathways, while the direct conversion of CO2 and CH4 to produce acetic acid is an attractive route to mitigate global warming and emission of greenhouse gases (Scheme 41). Using two gases with greenhouse effects, this route of acetic acid synthesis is considered green and represents an atom economical reaction. Nevertheless, the inertness of both molecules CH4 and CO2 makes this conversion very difficult and thermodynamically limited. Calculation of Gibbs energy showed an increase, ΔG = 71.17 kJ mol−1,324 and, the development of an efficient catalyst to overcome the kinetic barrier constitutes a great challenge.
Scheme 41 Direct synthesis of acetic acid from CO2 and methane.

Many heterogeneous catalytic systems have been developed such as Cu/Co supported on oxide,325 Pd and Pt on carbon or alumnina,326 Pd or Rh on silica.327 Nevertheless, up to now these catalysts have exhibited poor selectivity, low acetic acid yield and turnover frequency, and operate at high temperature, >425 °C.


4.2.2 Zeolite based catalysts for acetic acid synthesis.
(a) Zeolite-based catalysts containing Cu and Fe for acetic acid synthesis. Recently, zeolites, especially metal ion-modulated zeolites, were found to be highly active in the dissociation of the C–H bond328 of methane and the C–C coupling between the methyl group (–CH3) and CO2.329 Accordingly, numerous studies have focused on the activation of CH4 molecules in metal exchanged zeolites.330,331 Naturally, CH4 is converted into methanol by the methane monooxygenase (MMO) enzymes using Cu and Fe as active metals. Two forms of monooxygenase exist, cytoplasmic (soluble) and membrane-bound (particulate) with different active sites, a bis(m-oxo)diiron332 and Cu cluster,333,334 respectively, the latter catalyzing the oxygen insertion into the C–H methane bond. Different studies attributed the catalytic activity to a Cu dimer334 or to a trinuclear Cu cluster.335

Accordingly, numerous catalytic systems based on iron and copper–oxygen species in inorganic matrices were studied for methane oxidation. One of the most promising catalysts is the copper and iron exchanged zeolites. Following these leads, different catalytic systems were designed and explored to determine the nature of active Cu-clusters for the conversion of CH4 into methanol. Recently,336 a study of cationic species in Cu-MOR materials showed that, in contrast to other metal-modulated zeolites337,338 where different cationic species are present, in Cu-MOR only homogeneous single sites are anchored. Trinuclear Cu-oxo clusters, [Cu3(μ-O)3]2+, anchored to two framework Al atoms located at the pore mouth of the 8-MR side pockets were well described. Moreover, these trinuclear Cu-oxo clusters were shown to be highly stable under dry conditions. The C–H bond activation of methane molecules to methanol production has been the objective of many studies. Despite the efforts and numerous works, the nature of the active sites and the mechanism of activation of both CH4 and CO2 molecules and their conversion into acetic acid on metal modulated zeolites are still the subject of numerous discussions and studies. A general mechanism of bifunctional activation with the formation of metal methyl species and CO2 protonation is favoured and depicted in the Scheme 42.329,339,340


Scheme 42 Possible scheme for direct conversion of CH4 and CO2 over metal-modulated zeolite.

Modelling studies have been most useful for a deeper understanding of the catalysis of metal-modulated zeolites for the direct conversion of CH4 and CO2. A recent theoretical study over Cu-modulated BEA, MFI, MOR and TON zeolites was performed by means of DFT calculations. The results showed that the catalytic activity of Cu-modulated zeolites is closely related to the structure of both active copper species and zeolite pore channels. The isomorphic substitution of the Si atom with the Al atom in the zeolite framework induces a negative charge that is compensated by mononuclear [Cu]2+, binuclear [CuOCu]2+, or trinuclear [Cu3(μ-O)3]2+ clusters.341 The study showed that under specific catalyst activation conditions, different Cu-cationic species can be preferentially stabilized in the corresponding optimized structures. The authors showed that [CuOCu]2+ is preferentially stabilized in the three-dimensional BEA and MFI zeolites while [Cu3(μ-O)3]2+ is preferentially stabilized in the one-dimensional MOR and TON zeolites. Experimental data reported in the bibliography also indicated that binuclear [CuOCu]2+ in the MFI zeolite342 exhibited high activity, while trinuclear [Cu3(μ-O)3]2+ was the dominant active sites in the MOR zeolite.343 Zeolites incorporating [CuOCu]2+ and [Cu3(μ-O)3]2+ species showed to be active for the direct conversion of CH4 and CO2, in comparison with the mononuclear copper ([Cu]2+) species. Specifically, the authors claimed that [CuOCu]2+ in the MFI and BEA zeolites are suitable to stabilize the transition state of the rate-determining C–C coupling by electrostatic forces and reduce the free energy and enthalpy barrier. On the other hand, the authors claimed the ability of [Cu3(μ-O)3]2+ present in the MOR zeolite to stabilize the transition state of the C–C coupling (Fig. 13). The differences in stabilization ability, resulted in a higher catalytic activity with a low apparent activation energy (57 kJ mol−1) in the MOR zeolite with [Cu3(μ-O)3]2+ clusters.


Fig. 13 Direct conversion of carbon dioxide and methane to acetic acid over Cu-modulated zeolites. Reprinted with permission from ref. 337. Copyright 2019, Royal Society of Chemistry.

In an experimental study in continuous fixed-bed reactor using Cu-exchanged M-ZSM-5 (M = Li+, Na+, K+ and Ca++), a synergetic effect between metallic Cu species and the basic cations was suggested to allow the simultaneous activation of CH4 and CO2 molecules to form acetic acid.329 The nature of the metallic Cu species was not discussed, and previous reduction of the catalyst was carried out before its use to prevent the formation of CuOx. The results showed that the CO2 activation was dependent on the alkali cations, favouring the CO2 insertion into C–H activated bond of CH4. Cationic properties such as size (Li < Na < K) and cation charge control both charge density and number of cations. Cu–Ca-ZSM5 exhibited the lowest activity. Adsorption studies revealed the higher CO2 adsorption capacity of Cu–K-ZSM5, attributed to the acid–base interaction between the ZSM-5 framework and CO2 molecules. Cu–Na-ZSM-5 catalyst gave the highest rate of acetic acid formation at the initial period but showed a higher deactivation after 1 h than Cu–K-ZSM-5. At 9 min of TOS, 18% of CH4 conversion and acetic acid yield can be achieved, at 500 °C in the presence of the Cu–Na-ZSM-5 catalyst. However, after 1 h, 0.6 and 0.15% of CH4 conversion and acetic acid yield, respectively, were obtained. The best acetic acid production (0.395 mmol gcat−1 h−1) was registered on the Cu–K-ZSM-5 catalyst, at 500 °C, for 10 h. The recyclability of the catalyst was shown and the regenerated catalysts exhibited similar activities to the fresh catalysts (close to 70% acetic acid). The deactivation was mainly due to Cu0 aggregation that could be re-dispersed via a calcination process.

Another theoretical study explored the effect of the metal cations within the zeolite for the direct conversion of CO2 and CH4 to acetic acid. The analysis and comparison of the catalytic properties of MFI zeolites exchanged with Be, Co, Cu, Mg, Mn and Zn cations to compensate the charge induced by the substitution of two Al atoms, was addressed.344 The location of the exchanged metal was within the six-member ring located at the surface of the straight channel. The calculation results showed CH4 dissociation is the rate-determining step, and CH4 dissociation and the free energy barriers of CH4 dissociation and C–C bond coupling were related to the electronegativity of the metal cation. Therefore, the lowest apparent activation energy of 11.5 kcal mol−1 was obtained over the Cu-MFI. Additionally, the authors showed that the co-adsorption of H2O allowed to reduce the acetic acid desorption energy which can be reduced from 42.0 to 20.5 kcal mol−1.


(b) Zeolite based catalysts containing Zn for acetic acid synthesis. Numerous investigations on the activation of C–H bond, for methanol or acetic acid production have reported the effect of the local structure of the active sites. Following this, the activity of Zn modified H-ZSM-5 containing isolated Zn2+ cations or small ZnO clusters was studied by means of DFT.340 The conversion of CH4 and CO2 revealed to be strongly dependent on the local structure of the active sites. Thus, Zn2+ cations located in the 5-membered rings of the sinusoidal and straight channels exhibited the best catalytic activity, higher than other Zn2+ cations or small ZnO clusters owing to suitable adsorption properties of CH4 and CO2 and favourable activation energies. Previously, a work based on solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, reported the direct conversion of CH4 and CO2 into acetic acid on zinc-modified H-ZSM-5 (Zn/H-ZSM-5), at low temperature (250–500 °C), and described the reaction mechanism.345 The nature of Zn species was not discussed but the efficient activity and selectivity of the bifunctional zeolite was shown. As was proposed,346,347 the selective formation of methyl-metal species from methane was confirmed (zinc methyl species (–Zn–CH3)) with the simultaneously formation of protons. This mechanism can be well accepted in analogy to the activity of organozinc compounds.348 The adsorption of CO2 on the surface provides a reservoir for CO2 to be inserted into the Zn–C bond. Finally, the zeolite framework offers excellent ability to stabilize and transfer Brønsted protons and to protonate the surface acetate species (Fig. 14).
Fig. 14 Mechanism to the activation of CH4 and the formation of zinc methyl species and Brønsted proton, while CO2 activation led to the formation of carbonate species (Steps 1 and 2). The insertion of CO2 into zinc methyl species provided surface acetate species that produced acetic acid upon protonation with the restoration of Zn/H-ZSM-5 catalyst (Steps 1 and 2). Reprinted with permission from ref. 345. Copyright 2013, American Chemical Society.

Currently, it is well accepted that the catalytic activity is determined by the structure and nature of the active sites. The results of adsorption energies for zinc-modified H-ZSM-5 catalysts showed that adsorption strength of CH4 was dependent on Zn2+ cation location and decreased in the following order for the four-, five-, and six-membered rings in straight and sinusoidal channels, Z4 > Z5 > Z6 and M5 > M6, respectively, accordingly to the charge distribution of Zn/H-ZSM-5 based on the Mulliken charge analysis. Consequently, Zn2+ cations located in the 5-membered rings of the channels (straight and sinusoidal) exhibited better catalytic activity than other isolated Zn2+ sites and small ZnO clusters due to the favourable adsorption properties of reactants and activation energies.340


(c) Zeolite-based catalysts containing Au for acetic acid synthesis. The possible reaction mechanism for the direct formation of acetic acid from CH4 and CO2 over the Au-exchanged ZSM-5A has been explored by DFT study, involving Brønsted acid sites to the CO2 protonation and Au(I) active center to the formation methyl-gold species.339 The formation of methyl-gold species go through the CH4 molecule activation over the Au(I) active center in which the C–H dissociation proceed via the homolytic σ-bond activation, the calculated energy barrier for methane dissociation on Au-ZSM-5 being only 10.5 kcal mol−1. The methyl-gold species are very stable and the CO2 insertion difficult, 52.9 kcal mol−1 being the activation energy of the concerted mechanism (Fig. 15). The understanding of acetic acid formation over exchanged zeolites is a valuable contribution in the path to the design of more efficient catalysts.
Fig. 15 Energy profile for the acetic acid formation via the concerted bi-functional mechanism. Bond distances are in Å and energies are in kcal mol−1. Reprinted with permission from ref. 339. Copyright 2012, Royal Society of chemistry.

4.2.3 Conclusions. The reported works provide relevant and crucial insights about the mechanism of the direct conversion of CO2 and CH4 into acetic acid within the pores of microporous materials, the limiting step and barrier energies that catalytic systems must overcome. The structure and composition of the zeolite framework stabilize extraframework metal species that are able to activate methane and form methyl-metal species. Up to now, among the few reported experimental data, the best results were achieved in the presence of Cu–K-ZSM-5 catalyst with 0.395 mmol gcat−1 h−1 acetic acid production, at 500 °C, for 10 h.329 The synthesis of an efficient catalyst with active sites for the simultaneous activation of CH4 activation and CO2 insertion remains crucial and challenging. Thus, the catalyst based on zeolite or OMS should have metal active sites for CH4 activation, adequate CO2 adsorption capacity and CO2 insertion activity that will be achieved by the incorporation of Lewis acid sites, basic sites and oxygen vacancies. So far, important insights have been made using both experimental and theoretical approaches. However, systemic study and understanding of reaction mechanisms, determination of reaction intermediates and catalyst active species by computational studies and in situ characterization are imperative. Furthermore, a performing reaction system should be designed to overcome the limitations of thermodynamic equilibrium and improve the production of acetic acid. In addition, a reaction system using plasma could offer new opportunities.
4.3 Synthesis of propanoic acid. Propanoic acid finds wide application as an intermediate in the synthesis of commodity chemicals and polymers, and used as a preservative in food. Propanoic acid is mainly produced by hydrocarboxylation of ethylene in the presence of Pd(AcO)2349 and could be ideally prepared from the insertion of CO2 into ethane (Scheme 43). To overcome thermodynamic limitations the design and preparation of new catalysts is a great challenge. Very few references are reported in the bibliography concerning the preparation of propanoic acid from CO2.
Scheme 43 Direct synthesis of propanoic acid from CO2 and ethane.

In analogy with the synthesis of acetic acid, metal modulated zeolite can be good candidates to activate CO2 and C–H bond to allow the insertion of CO2 into ethane. In this sense, the activation of short chain alkanes and specially ethane over zeolites has been reported.350,351 Accordingly, a theoretical study using density functional theory (DFT) has recently investigated possible reaction pathways for the conversion of CO2 and C2H6 to propanoic acid over Au-exchanged MCM-22 zeolite catalyst.352 The insertion of CO2 was envisioned following two different routes. The first one involves only the metal center, the CO2 insertion into the Au-H bond followed by the C–C coupling and the formation of propanoic acid with an activation energy for the rate-determining step of 48.2 kcal mol−1. The second route involves the metal center and framework Brønsted acid sites with the formation of gold ethyl hydride species with the corresponding transfer of hydrogen to the oxygen framework providing the Brønsted-acid site, followed by the protonation of CO2 and the simultaneous C–C coupling. In this second case, the activation energy is 44.2 kcal mol−1 and it is the favoured route, at low temperatures (Scheme 44). The authors estimated that an increase of temperature could be enough to overcome the barrier energy to perform the direct insertion of CO2 into ethane in the presence of Au-exchanged MCM-22.


Scheme 44 Proposed mechanism for the direct synthesis of propanoic acid from CO2 and ethane over Au/MCM-22 catalyst.
4.4 Conclusions. Carboxylic acids would ideally be produced from the direct reaction of carbon dioxide with alkanes and some studies provide essential data to rationalize the activity and selectivity for the conversion of CO2 and alkanes to carboxylic acids. However, the use of CO2 as a renewable building block for the synthesis of carboxylic acids via green processes is still at an early stage and, despite great scientific interest and advantages, remains a big challenge. Different synthetic routes involving the use of activated substrates, stoichiometric organometallic reagents, reducing agents, salts, with the co-production of large amounts of residues present some achievements but they have significant drawbacks. Undoubtedly, the development of efficient and multifunctional heterogeneous catalysts is crucial. Computational chemistry and in situ spectroscopy should be important tools to provide in-depth knowledge determine the active species and reaction intermediates that will enable the design of new catalysts and processes to achieve environmental and economic goals. Zeolite and OMS will definitely play a crucial role due to their unique tunable properties and their chemical and thermal stability. So far, CO2 fixation in carboxylic acids remains unattainable from an industrial point of view.

5 Hydrogenation of CO2

Hydrogen is a promising fuel but it lacks the energy density required for practical use. Conversion of CO2 and hydrogen into liquid fuels such as methane or methanol, via Power-to-Liquid (PtL) processes, is more desirable from an energy density perspective. Moreover, considering the intermittence of renewable sources to produce H2,353 CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, methane or dimethylether can provide an important approach to store energy. However, a significant improvement in catalyst technology for CO2 conversion is required for carbon capture and utilization to become an economically viable alternative. Hydrogen can be produced from fossil sources such as natural gas and coal, and from water electrolysis using electricity from nuclear plants or from renewable sources, such as wind, solar, geothermal, and hydroelectric power. Therefore, to fulfill the concepts of sustainability and green chemistry and make CO2 hydrogenation a valuable strategy, hydrogen has to be green and produced from non-fossil sources. Currently, different approaches to green H2 production, such as water electrolysis using fuel cells, the biomass thermo-chemical process, anaerobic fermentation and water splitting through photo-electrolysis, are being considered.
5.1 Hydrogenation/reduction of CO2 to formic acid. For several CO2 conversions, the enthalpy changes revealed that transformations are exothermic despite the high stability of CO2. Nevertheless, in almost all cases, the Gibbs free energy changes are positive and thermodynamically unfavoured.354–357 Negative Gibbs free energy changes often correspond to the hydrogenation reaction where very stable compounds, such as water, are produced, or to CO2 transformation where C–O bonds are not broken.358 Although CO2 transformations are not thermodynamically favourable, in practice, by working under adequate conditions such as pressure, temperature and ratio of reactants, processes involving CO2 activation and reactions must be possible and of clear interest. Hydrogenation/reduction processes are attractive and valuable processes even if it is still challenging to convert CO2 into platform molecules with high activity and selectivity. If this is achieved and industrially applied, it will impact our daily life, economy, CO2 mitigation, environment and climatic changes.
5.1.1 Introduction. Formic acid is the simplest organic acid. It is eco-friendly, noncorrosive, easily biodegradable, and a valuable chemical used as a dye in the textile and leather industries, as an intermediate in the chemical and pharmaceutical industry,359 a green solvent and moreover a promising hydrogen storage component. Reversible processes of hydrogenation/dehydrogenation make possible the hydrogen storage through the formation of formic acid from CO2 hydrogenation, and the decomposition into CO2 and H2 is thermodynamically downhill (Scheme 45).360,361
Scheme 45 Reversible hydrogen storage.

The current industrial methods for formic acid production include hydrolysis of methyl formate or formamide, oxidation of biomass359 and the reaction of CO with water.362 All these methods lead to the production of hazardous wastes and high energetic costs. According to the report of Coval Energy, the global annual demand for formic acid was around 870 ktons in 2021 with a forecasted compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 3.87% during the period 2022–2027.363

Direct hydrogenation of CO2 into formic acid is a green and 100% atom economy reaction allowing to mitigate CO2 emissions and to store H2 in a liquid form. CO2 hydrogenation is an important approach to use CO2 to produce C1 chemicals but it is still challenging due to CO2 inertness and stability. Moreover, this conversion is entropically disfavoured since it involves a phase change from gaseous reagents into a liquid product (Scheme 46).


Scheme 46 Hydrogenation of CO2 into formic acid.

Significant progress in the development of highly efficient and robust homogeneous catalytic systems, especially Ru362,364 and Ir-based metallic complex requiring the use of a co-catalyst such as phosphines, amines or carbonate salts, has been achieved.365–368 Nevertheless, in spite of their excellent catalytic performance in terms of activity and selectivity369 with TON and TOF of up to 110000 h−1,370 several drawbacks such as toxicity, difficult separation of formic acid or formic acid derivatives and the absence of recyclability of the homogeneous catalysts make it necessary to develop efficient, robust and recyclable catalytic systems.371,372


5.1.2 Zeolite-based catalysts for formic acid synthesis. Heterogeneous catalysts have been widely explored for formic acid production from CO2 in the presence of nanoparticulate noble and non-noble metals supported on carbon, metal oxides and silica,373 see for instance, RANEY® nickel in the presence of amines,374 synthesized nanoporous nickel,375 Pd/C,376 and Au/TiO2.377 However, only few works have studied the potential catalytic properties of zeolite based catalysts for this reaction.

Virtual screening is an important tool to avoid or support tedious studies based on experimental trial and error studies. Computational screening is a method that broadly combines computational algorithms for selecting promising candidates from a large library of materials. The combination of the modular building-block approach and the potential for computational screening has allowed the introduction of the Materials Genome Initiative (MGI) to “discover, develop, and deploy new materials twice as fast”.378 MGI attempts to combine theory, computation, synthesis, and characterization to boost the discovery and synthesis of new materials.379 In agreement, a computational screening of well-known zeolites as great catalysts combining molecular simulation and machine-learning techniques is of much use for advancing synthesis and reactivity380–383 and also for conversion of CO2 into useful products.384 In this study, the combination of adsorption simulations, dual-adsorption models, energy–entropy calculations, and statistical and machine learning modelling techniques allowed establishing structure–property relationships based on structural characteristics (pore size, surface area, and voids) and zeolite performance for the production of methane, methanol, formic acid and formaldehyde. Therefore, promising zeolite candidates were determined to have a cavity size of around 6 Å to maximize the strength of dual-adsorption of hydrogen and CO2. Then, the possible mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid using Lewis acid zeolites has been investigated by using density functional theory (DFT).385 The CO2 hydrogenation and formate ion formation was considered to be the rate-determining step for Sn-ZSM-5 zeolites. The activation barrier was calculated for both perfect (38.2 kcal mol−1) and defect Lewis center (33.0 kcal mol−1). A Sn-ZSM-5 active site allows minimizing the activation energy in comparison to Sn-BEA or Sn-FAU. The order of activation energy for the metal center was determined to be Hf > Zr > Sn > Ge, which is dependent on the charge transfer from the catalytic active site to the reacted molecule. This result showed the importance of charge transfer from the metal to CO2 for the activation of the CO bonds and also the H–H bond breaking via oxygen abstraction at the Sn–OH sites of defect zeolites.

Recent studies showed the good catalytic properties of molecular-sized Ir4 clusters stabilized in FAU and MWW zeolites for hydrogenation and dehydrogenation reactions.51,386,387 Accordingly, a theoretical work reporting the CO2 mechanism to produce formic acid catalyzed by faujasite-supported Ir4 clusters was reported.388 Both hydrogenation of CO2 into CO, thermodynamically favoured, and hydrogenation of CO2 into formic acid, kinetically preferred under water free-conditions, can take place. The important effect of confined water cooperation for both hydrogenation processes was shown. The co-adsorbed water molecule facilitates the H+ transfer step by a water molecule between the zeolite Brønsted acid sites and Ir4 cluster. However, if the formation of the Ir–COOH carboxyl moiety is facilitated by the presence of water this latter also promotes the selective decarbonylation of COOH species and the production of CO. The authors so concluded that it is impossible to obtain formic acid in the presence of water using Ir4/FAU as the catalyst, and that only an effective water-removal and optimized process could ensure the selective formation of formic acid.


5.1.3 OMS-based catalysts for formic acid synthesis. The immobilization of homogeneous catalysts via covalent bonding is an alternative to overcome the problems of separation and to improve the environmental impact and costs, by combining the advantages of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis. This strategy has received a lot of interest for the preparation of formic acid.372,389–391

Following the above direction, MCM-41 functionalized with γ-NH2, CN and SH-propyl trimethoxysilane incorporating RuCl3 were prepared and tested in the hydrogenation of CO2 into formic acid, at 80 °C, 5.4 MPa H2 and 9.3 MPa CO2 (SC) partial pressures, 1 h and in the presence of ethanol as the solvent.392 The importance of the nature and use of a solvent as well as of the ligands showed the influence on the activity of the MCM-41 immobilized ruthenium complex. The three types of MCM-41 immobilized ruthenium complexes exhibited a TON of up to 1022. Nevertheless, the stability of the catalyst was limited. The structured mesoporous material with SH groups showed the best stability but the lowest activity while the material with NH2 groups exhibited lower stability but better activity. The differences in activity and stability were attributed to the complexation ability of the different groups (NH2, CN and SH). More recently, the preparation and catalytic performance of SiO2 and MCM-41 supported Ruthenium materials for the selective hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid, at 80 °C, 40 bar (PH2:PCO2 = 1:2) were reported.393 In terms of TON/TOF values, Ru/MCM-41 exhibited higher catalytic performance than Ru/SiO2 due to its textural properties and large surface area that allow high metal dispersion. Additionally, the catalytic performance of Ru/MCM-41 was improved with the use of sulfated and fluorinated ionic liquid [DAMI][CF3CF2CF2CF2SO3] (DAMI = 1,3-di(N,N -dimethylaminoethyl)-2-methylimidazolium). In this way, the production of formic acid with TON value up to 1780 with Ru/MCM-41 in [DAMI] [CF3CF2CF2CF2SO3] ionic liquid medium and the stability of catalytic properties in the presence of water were demonstrated. The recyclability of the catalyst was shown and Ru/MCM-41 in [DAMI] [CF3CF2CF2CF2SO3] was recycled eight times with practically no loss of activity. This catalytic reaction system offers a green attempt to the production of formic acid and can be used as a leading direction for further developments.


5.1.4 Conclusion. This short review of the state-of-the-art related to the use of ordered microporous and mesoporous based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation into formic acid clearly revealed that the potential of these types of materials has been underconsidered despite the requirement of a novel catalytic system for the challenging formic acid production as a hydrogen storage material.

Indeed, the direct hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid is an ideal reaction with 100% atom economy. Nevertheless, at the same time, it is a very challenging task since activating both H2 and CO2 molecules is a hard task, and CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid is thermodynamically unfavored. Moreover, to achieve a higher yield and turnover number, stoichiometric amounts of organic or inorganic bases (DBU, NaOH, KOH, K2CO3, and TEA) are widely used to shift the thermodynamic equilibrium to formate. Note that the present reaction procedure requires further neutralization steps with a stoichiometric amount of acid that produces a high amount of salts and waste, and tedious recovery of formic acid. To achieve environmental and economic goals, a greener and more efficient process is imperative, and heterogeneous catalysts are very valuable, attractive, and prime candidates. Thus, an efficient catalyst will have active centers to adsorb and activate hydrogen (metal species) based on noble metals (Ru, Rh, Pd, and Au) and other metals such as Co, Ni, Cu and Fe, high CO2 adsorption capacity and CO2 activation, which will be achieved by the incorporation of acidic and basic Lewis sites and oxygen vacancies. Undoubtedly, the support will play a key role in adsorbing CO2, and dispersing and stabilizing the different active species. Zeolite and OMS will be major players due to their unique and tunable properties (high surface area, Lewis and Brønsted acid/base properties, and chemical and thermal stability). In addition, a thorough understanding of the reaction mechanism, kinetics and determination of the active species and reaction intermediates will only be possible through computational chemistry and in situ spectroscopy studies, fundamental tools for the design of new catalysts and processes.

5.2 Hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol.
5.2.1 Introduction. In the context of H2 and CO2 conversion into liquid fuels via Power-to-Liquid processes, methanol production from CO2 is of much interest. Methanol is a large scale product with an industrial production capacity of about approximately 140 million metric tons in 2018 that is expected to double to reach 280 million metric tons by 2030.394 Industrial production of methanol is from synthesis gas mixtures (H2/CO2/CO) at high pressures (50–100 bar) and temperatures (200–300 °C) over Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts.395 Methanol constitutes an important chemical feedstock and a platform molecule to produce a large variety of bulk commodities396 and fuels397 for engines and fuel cells. Numerous methanol commodity derivatives are produced for their use in our daily life such as paints, polymers, plastics, resins, adhesives, and antifreezes. Taking into account the potential of methanol, George A. Olah and co-workers395 published in 2006 a report of current fossil fuels as energy sources and future alternative sources. There, they discuss the important and future role of methanol and advocated the “methanol economy” whose concept purveys the idea that methanol can be used as an alternative way for storing, transporting and using energy.398

Fig. 16 illustrates the importance of methanol as carbon feedstock obtained from green hydrogenation of CO2 to reach carbon neutrality, and a crucial pathway to reach circularity. One of the most promising route to produce methanol is the direct CO2 hydrogenation. The development of active catalysts and specially zeolite-based catalysts for the conversion of methanol to olefins (MTO),399–403 aromatics, propylene (MTP), dimethyl ether404,405 and fuels406 will play a key role due to the flexibility in their catalytic properties such as the versatility in their composition and the nature of the active sites, robustness, stability and ready availability of zeolites and OMS, and should mark a new breakthrough in the field of molecular sieves.


Fig. 16 Importance of methanol as carbon feedstock obtained from green hydrogenation of CO2 to reach carbon neutrality.

5.2.2 Thermodynamics for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Methanol is typically synthesized from syngas (H2 + CO) obtained from fossil fuels.371,407 This process is highly exothermic and the major challenge is to control and remove heat excess to shift the equilibrium towards methanol production minimizing side reactions and catalyst sintering. The commercial catalyst generally contains Cu and a mixture of oxides such as ZnO/Al2O3 and operates under relatively “soft” conditions, 210–270 °C and 50–100 bar.408 The main side products are higher alcohols, methane, methyl formate and dimethyl ether. The formation of methanol by direct hydrogenation of CO2 constitutes an alternative and a challenging route. Direct hydrogenation of CO2 competes directly with reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) and the large production of water has a severe negative effect over the catalyst life and the performance of ternary catalyst Cu–ZnO–Al2O3. Moreover, the hydrophilic properties of alumina favour sintering and aggregation of metals. CO produced from RWGS can undergo hydrogenation into methanol (Scheme 47). From thermodynamics standpoint, the enthalpy variation shows that CO and CO2 hydrogenations are exothermic and involve a decrease of volume which indicates that the use of lower reaction temperatures and higher pressures is thermodynamically favourable, while the reverse water-gas-shift reaction is strongly endothermic (Scheme 47). However, a higher temperature favours CO2 activation, while an increase in temperature also promotes the undesirable formation of CO and H2O, limiting CO2 conversion.
Scheme 47 Formation of methanol by direct hydrogenation of CO2 and CO produced from RWGS.

5.2.3 Mechanism insights for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. A thorough understanding of the reaction mechanism and how the catalyst participates should help to realise a molecular design of a catalyst able to work at low temperature (<200 °C). Two main kinetic expressions have been reported for the formation of methanol considering the commercial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst.409,410 The first kinetic model considers the formation of methanol from both CO and CO2 whereas the second model only considers CO2 as the source of methanol. Despite the large number of mechanistic studies based on the theoretical and experimental data, the mechanism of methanol synthesis from CO2 remains controversial as evidence for the formation of both, formate,411–413 being the hydrogenation of HCOO to H3CO the rate-limiting step,414 and CO, as intermediates415–417 (Scheme 48). Indeed, some reports postulate that the first step of the direct hydrogenation of CO2 is the formate intermediate formation, while others propose that RWGS takes place followed by CO hydrogenation into methanol.416Scheme 49 illustrates the possible oxygenated products produced from CO2 hydrogenation.
Scheme 48 Proposed reaction mechanism for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol according to different studies.

Scheme 49 Possible oxygenated products obtained from CO2 hydrogenation.

5.2.4 Catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. There are more than 200 papers published in the last decade dealing with the hydrogenation of CO2 into methanol. Nevertheless, few studies reported the direct hydrogenation of CO2 into MeOH using zeolite based catalysts. However, the textural properties of ordered mesoporous silica have been used to disperse the metal-oxide active phase and to take advantage of the confinement. Due to the enhanced catalytic performance of the ternary catalyst Cu/ZnO/Al2O3, and the similarity between syngas-to-methanol conversion, Cu-based and Cu/ZnO based materials have been extensively investigated. Up to now, Cu is regarded as the main active component for CO2 hydrogenation and ZnO is regarded to promote hydrogen spillover and the dispersion of Cu nanoparticles. Numerous papers described the catalytic performance of catalysts based on Cu and/or Pd.371,418 Actually, bifunctional metal-zeolite based materials are preferentially used for the synthesis of dimethylether, olefins or aromatics since it is possible to take advantage of the acid properties of these materials and shift the process selectivity avoiding competitive side reactions. Indeed, the presence of multinuclear metal centers and active sites in a single solid catalyst presents several advantages over mononuclear catalysts due to the cooperativity effect between the different centers such as synergetic activation of substrates and electronic interactions between the metal centers, which is potentially beneficial to the catalytic activity. Hence, investigations have focussed on the preparation of metal oxides with excellent activity and stability for the hydrogenation of CO2 and efficient catalysts should exhibit high specific surface area, high number of active sites, high dispersion, optimum acid/base site distribution, and small particle size in order to increase the activity and selectivity to methanol.
(a) OMS-based catalysts for CO2 conversion to methanol. (i) Cu/OMS-based catalysts for CO2conversion to methanol. Cu is a good monometallic catalyst for methanol synthesis419 but, if used alone, results in low catalytic rates and selectivity towards methanol. However, the Cu catalytic performance can be enhanced by forming a Cu/ZnO active phase. Indeed, pure Cu surface is shown to convert CO2 to CO, while combination of Cu and ZnO greatly boosts the methanol formation,420 since the use of metal oxides allows high dispersion and stabilization of Cu due to special metal/metal interaction, basicity, reducibility properties and oxygen lattice, that favour the coordination and activation of CO2, maximizing the catalyst activity for methanol synthesis.421,422 So far, Cu/ZnO catalysts for industrial applications or theoretical research are still in the forefront of the investigation due to their prominent catalytic properties.422,423 The studies to improve Cu-based catalysts properties for CO2 hydrogenation into MeOH focus on improving the Cu nanoparticle dispersion by varying the preparation method and/or metal precursors and by incorporating promoters.424,425

To optimize the catalytic features, the understanding and definition of the nature of active sites in Cu/ZnO is fundamental. The metal oxide interface is crucial to enhance and create catalytic ability and the synergy of Cu and ZnOx at the interface was shown to promote the methanol synthesis.426,427 Nevertheless, destructive effects of the hydrothermal reaction conditions induce a rupture at the Cu–ZnOx interface, sintering of Cu particles that modify the catalytic properties and decrease methanol selectivity.428,429

The interaction between Cu and oxide components enables the formation of Cu–MOx (M = Zn and/or Zr) active species at the Cu–MOx interface and the catalytic activity depends on the interaction between Cu and metal oxide components.430 Therefore, the confinement or encapsulation431 of Cu–MOx on the walls of porous materials was considered as a promising route to improve the metal dispersion and the sintering resistance, and thus enhance the stability and selectivity of the catalytic system to methanol production. Accordingly, due to their textural properties (high surface areas, thermal and chemical stability and pore-size) ordered mesoporous materials offer opportunities to well-disperse and stabilize Cu–MOx or other active metal-oxide compounds (Fig. 17).


Fig. 17 High dispersion and stabilization of metal–MOx (active metal–oxide phase) on OMS.

(ii) Binary OMS-based catalysts for CO2hydrogenation to methanol. As we mentioned above, the application of Cu alone-catalysts are limited due to the low stability and selectivity to MeOH. Therefore, modified catalysts with MOx (Ce, Mn, Ga, Zr, and Ti) have been the purpose of many investigations due to the interfacial effects between the different metal phases that contribute to boost the catalytic performance of the final catalysts.432–434 In particular, the basic properties of some oxides are expected to enhance the adsorption/activation of CO2. For example, in Cu/ZrO2 catalysts, La doping promoted formate hydrogenation into MeOH and inhibited formate dissociation into CO.435 Following these leads, Cu–LaOx catalysts supported on SBA-15 were prepared wherein a Cu–LaOx interface was generated through the interaction of highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles with LaOx in the SBA-15 wall.436 The presence of LaOx species was beneficial to prevent the sintering of Cu and to enhance CO2 activation by adsorption of CO2 molecules at the Cu–LaOx interface. The optimized Cu1La0.2/SBA-15 catalyst displayed the best catalytic performance in terms of methanol selectivity (81.2%) and stability, with 5.7% CO2 conversion (Table 4, entry 2). The preparation and characterization of Cu–Ga/SBA-15 catalysts was also reported.437 The presence of Ga promotes the dispersion and stabilization of the Cu phase but also provides acidic sites with enhanced acidic strength due to the combination with silica. The addition of Ga improved the catalytic performance of the un-doped Cu-catalysts. 3% CO2 conversion and 71% MeOH + DME were reached with the Cu–Ga/SBA-15 catalyst (Table 4, entry 3). Attempts to disperse Cu/ZnO on SBA-15 (CZS), Al-SBA-15 (CZAS), Al2O3 (CZA) and Al2O3–ZrO2 (CZAZ) using impregnation methods were also investigated.438 The Cu/ZnO dispersed on the SBA-15 support presented the largest Cu surface area and dispersion, and the smallest particle size and was easily reduced. H2-TPR profiles showed two reduction peaks at 290 °C corresponding to the reduction of Cu2+ into Cu0 and the reduction of Cu2+ into Cu+ and into Cu0 at 337 °C. However, for Cu–ZnO/Al-SBA-15 (CZAS), a single and broad reduction peak at 370 °C was registered, attributed to strong metal–support interactions, in agreement with larger average particle size and lower metallic phase dispersion (Fig. 18). Thus, Cu/ZnO-SBA-15 exhibited the highest catalytic activity in comparison to Cu/ZnO–Al-SBA-15, Al2O3 and Al2O3/ZrO2-supported catalysts. The highest 91.32% methanol selectivity was obtained with the Cu/ZnO-SBA-15 catalyst with up to 14% CO2 conversion (Table 4, entries 4–6). The same group also studied the effect of the Cu/Zn ratio in Cu–Zn-SBA-15 catalysts on the catalytic performance in a fixed-bed.439 A positive effect of the incorporation of Zn was shown on Cu surface areas and dispersion, while a high Zn content induced an increase in the particle size and agglomeration of Cu. CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity increased while the Zn content decreased from 70% to 30%. This trend was attributed to the synergetic effect between Cu and ZnO that promotes H2 spillover. Then, a maximum 51.4 gMeOH h−1 gcat−1 productivity was reached for a metal ratio Cu:Zn = 7:3 and a linear relationship between the Cu surface area and methanol productivity was shown, with 14.2% CO2 conversion and 92.1% MeOH selectivity (Table 4, entry 7).

Table 4 Comparison of the catalytic data of the different M-oxides supported on OMS for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol
Entry Catalystb T °C, pressure (MPa) CO2 conv. (%) CH3OH sel. (%) CH3OH, STY (mgCH3OH gcat−1 h−1) GHSV (mL gcat−1 h−1) Year Ref.
Ratio H2:CO2 = 3:1, fixed bed.a 3 mL HPHT cell (Harrick Scientific).b Metal content is given in wt%.

3 10Cu–5Ga/SBA-15 250 °C, 2.5 MPa 3 71 N/A CO2:Ar:H2 = 5:5:15, GHSV = 30000 h−1 2018 437
4 4.5Cu–10.5Zn/Al-SBA-15 210 °C, 2.25 MPa 14 91.3 N/A H2:CO2 = 3:1, no data for GHSV 2017 438
5 4.5Cu–10.5Zn/SBA-15 210 °C, 2.25 MPa 12 80 N/A 2017 438
6 4.5Cu–10.5Zn/Al2O3 210 °C, 2.25 MPa 11 77 N/A 2017 438

8 15Cu/Zr-SBA-15 250 °C, 3.3 MPa 15 27 N/A CO2:H2 = 1:3a 2017 440

10 15Cu/Zr-SBA-15_EIWI 250 °C, 3.3 MPa 6.5 92 N/A CO2:H2 = 1:3a 2019 442
Cu-based-ternary catalysts
11 6.6Cu–6.2Zn–7.5Zr/SBA-15 250 °C, 3 MPa 19.2 30.6 376 CO2:H2:N2 = 22.5:67.5:10, FT = 333 mL min−1, GHSV = 740 mL gcat−1 h−1 2019 443
12 39Cu–10Zn–2.6Mn/SBA-15 180 °C, 4 MPa 5.7 99 2236 GHSV = 120 L gcat−1 h−1, CO2:H2 = 1:3 2018 446
13 39Cu–10Zn–2.6Mn/KIT-6 180 °C, 4 MPa 8.2 99 3373 2018 446
